Looks good.

Regarding your open question:

> Should the compactor have a subscription so that it can cause messages to be retained until compaction occurs.

If I'm reading this correctly, you will need to make sure the topic is still around between passes so you will indeed require a cursor. On the first pass through you can read without acknowledgement and save acknowledgement until the second pass. This would also prevent a compact job that crashes anytime between the start and finish from missing data.
@rdhabalia Added tests with mocked DNS resolution

@joefk  would like to handle bookies in this issue this time, since zk seems easier to deploy and config, If needed, we could do it later.
#961 is for this issue.
I'm not really sure if removing `break` statement on `removeExpiredMessagesFromQueue` is a good thing, if messages on `incomingMessages` are guaranteed to be ordered there is no need to remove break.

Here are some notes about the discussion between @ivankelly @merlimat @mgodave and me:

- regarding "message deletion": it is okay either to use `empty content` as the delete message or use an explicit flag in message header to indicate that the message is a deletion message

- regarding client behavior reacting to `compacted data`
  * existing subscriptions (existing applications) should still read the `raw data` even the topic is configured to be a compacted topic
  * reading `compacted data` from a compacted topic should be explicitly called by a client through a flag or calling seek to earliest message of `compacted data`.
  * while reading `compacted data`, if a consumer/reader falls behind, by default it should just falls behind. fast-forward to new compacted data should be explicitly specified/configured in the consumer configuration.

@ivankelly @merlimat @mgodave - please take a look at these notes. let me know if I missed anything.

@rdhabalia Please take a look as well.

@merlimat, If we using config file way, we may also need reading the bookie-config-file from command-line. That means command line may have to change something, It is not purely through the broker config file.

Since we may have to change the cli, so changed to using purely cli options as it is now.

@zhaijack Right now, when starting broker, we default to `conf/broker.conf` and the same happens for bookies with `conf/bookkeeper.conf`. These are defined in `bin/pulsar`: 

```shell
DEFAULT_BROKER_CONF=$PULSAR_HOME/conf/broker.conf
DEFAULT_BOOKKEEPER_CONF=$PULSAR_HOME/conf/bookkeeper.conf
```

 We could continue that way, and use the `BOOKKEEPER_CONF` variable to locate the file.

@merlimat I realized that when a `ConsumerImpl` hands a message to `PartitionedConsumerImpl` it increases permits, so we should not increase permits when redelivering, this simplifies things a bit.
I also reworked `redeliverUnacknowledgedMessages()`.

Have you checked about the locks I mentioned in the PR? I believe there are some places where a write lock should be held but we currently only using read locks. This could have unforeseen conditions where we're modifying `pendingReceives` or `incomingMessages` while other may be reading them.

~~Another thing, when using `PartitionedConsumerImpl` does it make sense to set a `receiverQueueSize=1`? This would make the consumer use an `ArrayBlockingQueue` I don't know if this makes sense for partitioned topics because we use `incomingMessages.put` to insert messages in the queue, this would block almost every time for every partition delivering a message. If we remove the usage of `ArrayBlockingQueue` in `PartitionedConsumerImpl` we could change `incomingMessages.put` to `.add` and guard it with the write lock instead of read lock.~~
Just realised that `PartitionedConsumerImpl` always uses at least the number of partitions as its queue size, this means that it almost always should have `receiveQueueSize > 1`.
Instead creating multiple issues, is it fine if we can consolidate all compaction related issues in one?
@rdhabalia There will be a set of independent tasks, so we were planning to create a project to group of all of them.

@merlimat , Thanks for the info.  Excuse me for not expressing well.  
Regarding add an option in the broker config to run bookie together,   My concern is like this:

currently, command `PulsarBrokerStarter` is called as this:
``` 
$ PulsarBrokerStarter $DEFAULT_BROKER_CONF
```

If we set an option runBookieTogether in `broker.conf`, the command to run bookie together would be something like:
``` 
$ PulsarBrokerStarter $DEFAULT_BROKER_CONF $DEFAULT_BOOKKEEPER_CONF
```
In this way, both the broker.conf and command (PulsarBrokerStarter usage) need change. 
Since we may have to change the command(to add a new config file for bookie), so changed to using purely command line options maybe better.

The code in this code review, will provide a command like this:
``` 
$ PulsarBrokerStarter $DEFAULT_BROKER_CONF [--run-bookie] [--run-bookie-autorecovery] [ --bookie-conf $DEFAULT_BOOKKEEPER_CONF]
```
If we also provide a option in broker.conf, Does that mean `[--run-bookie]` and `[--run-bookie-autorecovery]` could be set through cli and also broker.conf?
If that is it, it may be confusing under some condition, like user set `not run-bookie` in broker.conf, but   set `run bookie` through cli.

This might be related to network stabilization in zookeeper.
Basically it takes time to stabilise the network of bookies as registered in zookeeper. You might want to look at the zookeeper property bkc.networkTopologyStabilizePeriodSeconds
Ref - https://twitter.github.io/distributedlog/html/implementation/storage.html

Do let us know if this issue is resolved.

@merlimat @rdhabalia It just occurred to me that with the changes in this PR `PartitionedConsumerImpl` uses listeners in an non-blocking fashion, maybe it would be sensitive to make internal consumers use the event loop as the listener executor, this would reduce the amount of active threads if only `PartitionedConsumerImpl` is used.
fyi, @lucperkins is working on this.

@mgodave The real question here is whether it matters if messages go away between the runs. If the messages go away, the client of the backlog wouldn't be able to read them anyhow, so why would they need to read them from the compacted topic.

I failed to add the last step in the "Release process" wiki. 

I've just promoted the last RC artifacts to be released in the ASF nexus repository. In a few hours they will be available on Maven central.

@sebbASF We have added the links for the keys in the download page. Please check whether it's correct now. https://pulsar.incubator.apache.org/download/

Sorry but the page is still incorrect.

KEYS, sigs and hashes must be linked from www.apache.org/dist/... and should use https.

Do not use the archive site (except for old releases that are no longer current)

The dist.apache.org host should never be used for public downloads.
It is only intended for use by developers during release voting and staging.

The "Other releases" section needs to make it clear that these are older releases.
Also there should be sigs and hashes for these. 
The current release KEYS file link (i.e. https://www.apache.org/dist/incubator/pulsar/KEYS) can also be used for past releases as RM keys should not be dropped, only added.

>  d. A new auth action is added which allows admin to restrict whether a topic is proxyable or not 

I don't think "proxy" it's a good match for an action.
An action in the ACLs is associated with a "role" while for proxy is just a flag

I would also like to eliminate the need for `TypedMessage<T>` and introduce `Message<T>` but as I tried to do it-it seemed quite invasive. I'll give it another try since it was early in my investigation.

@sschepens We had many issues with people having conflicts with different protobuf or netty versions and taking long time to debug those at runtime. 

I think shading by default is "nicer" to users. There is still the options to get unshaded client artifact by using `pulsar-client-original`. Do you think the option should be specified more prominently in the client documentation?

> I don't remember the last time I imported a library that was shaded.

Many libraries are actually doing that under the hood (eg: Netty, JCommander and many others).

>And ZK too. For small prod deployments,(eg: 2 broker, 3 BK system), running 5 ZK servers is too much. 

@joefk Main problem with ZK is that we have to provide list of hosts. 
It's a bit involved, but it could work if we do something like : 

`bin/pulsar broker --brokers-list brk-1,brk-2,brk-3` 

on each of the 3 nodes, to make sure they can form a quorum. It's more involved than starting the bookie though. And it's already possible to start the ZK process separately in the same nodes.

An unfortunate consequence of putting the listeners in the configuration objects is that the configurations need to be typed as well. I have some ideas on how to remove that and make subscribing with listeners more natural. I'll put that forward in another commit.

> I don't think "proxy" it's a good match for an action. An action in the ACLs is associated with a "role" while for proxy is just a flag

Should we rename the action to _lookup_ and add another or condition to  
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker-common/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/authorization/AuthorizationManager.java?utf8=%E2%9C%93#L109 


OR

Not add any Action and enforce that proxy has same AuthAcion permission as the client (produce and consume) - finer control
@merlimat done
